ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

OPENING OF PARLIAMENT
(Delay)


    1. Dr Tan Cheng Bock asked the Prime Minister why was the Opening of Parliament delayed for more than four months.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, there has not been any undue delay in the Opening of the New Parliament. The time between the General Elections and the Opening of Parliament

Column: 464

in the previous and the present instances was similar, being 144 days and 142 days respectively, or just about 20 weeks. In the earlier two general elections in 1988 and 1991, the interval was slightly shorter, about 18 weeks.

    Sir, a reasonable period of time between the General Elections and the Opening of Parliament is necessary to take stock of the tumultuous global and domestic developments, and to prepare policy positions and plans for our new term of office.

    But before the Opening of Parliament on 25th March, the Prime Minister, the Ministers, the PAP Members of Parliament reached out directly to our community leaders and the public to discuss the actions against the terrorists in Singapore, the new terrorist threats that we faced, communal and the tudung issues, as well as economic challenges we face. The Government also very quickly set up the Economic Review Committee to review our economic policies to revitalise the economy, and remake Singapore. So the Government has not been tardy since the General Elections. In other words, we have not been sitting on our hands.

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask the Minister whether we could convene Parliament one month after the General Elections, so that Parliament can be operationally ready in case there are urgent matters to discuss? I am sure Members of this House are fully aware that many issues happened after the General Elections, and this House has got no opportunity to discuss all these issues. Therefore, I would request that following General Elections in future, at least a month, we should all be sworn in and this House will be ready to tackle urgencies.

    Another question, Sir, is whether this is going to be the trend.

    Mr Wong Kan Seng: I do not think we can predict what would be the trend in the future because nobody can tell us what is going to happen in the future. While we can set some rules, I do not think we should be so rigid as to say that

Column: 465

we should meet immediately one month after the General Elections (GE). There could be many reasons why we cannot meet immediately. But if there are important or urgent reasons that we have to meet immediately after the GE, then there is no doubt that the Government will seize upon the opportunity to do so. But, here, we cannot commit that in future we will have a sitting one month after the GE. Much depends on the circumstances. I think the less we tie ourselves down with rules, the better it is. We should do what is necessary, what is useful, and what is important.

    Besides, immediately after the GE, there are many issues to be settled. Many of the programmes that the Government put up before the GE are ideas that we should pursue, and we need time to thrash them out; we need time to think through the major issues, and in this instance, for example, the key challenges we face today are economic restructuring and the new threat of the terrorists. So these are the two key challenges and therefore these are not issues that we can immediately come back to Parliament after the GE and settle. We cannot solve the problems even after the Budget. It will take some time for issues to be studied and to come out with programmes to resolve some of them. We cannot resolve all of them even in the Budget in May.

LAND RECLAMATION OFF PULAU TEKONG
(Impact on Malaysia)


    2. Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for National Development what is the situation regarding the land reclamation off Pulau Tekong and its possible impact on the Malaysians.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, there have been many reports in the Malaysian media alleging that our land reclamation works off Pulau Tekong and Tuas will impact Malaysia in various ways. We are surprised by these recent allegations since

Column: 466

our land reclamation policy is not new. Given Singapore's small size, it has been our long-standing policy to reclaim land from our territorial waters so as to meet the demands on land use. I will address these allegations in my response.

    First, there is concern that our works may encroach into their territorial waters, or somehow shift the boundary between Singapore and Malaysia. We have stated that the reclamation works are carried out entirely within our waters and that there is no encroachment. The reclamation works also cannot change the territorial boundary in the Johor Straits. This boundary was defined by fixed geographical coordinates since 1995 in an Agreement that was signed and ratified by Singapore and Malaysia.

    Another concern raised is that the reclamation works at Pulau Tekong will affect the shipping lane to Pasir Gudang Port by making the shipping lane narrower and shallower. Sir, this is not the case. The existing shipping lane to Pasir Gudang Port lies in the deep water channel between mainland Singapore and the islands of Pulau Ubin and Pulau Tekong. Ships going to our Sembawang Wharves also use this shipping lane. The current reclamation works at Pulau Tekong will not reduce or otherwise affect the existing width of this shipping lane. The shipping lane is not made shallower by the reclamation works. The Maritime Port Authority (MPA) regularly monitors the siltation levels within the shipping lane to ensure that the channel remains deep enough for navigation.

    In the case of Tuas, our reclamation works are about 7 km away from the shipping lane to Tanjung Pelepas Port, so there is no possibility that our reclamation would affect access to Tanjung Pelepas Port.

    I would also like to address allegations that the reclamation works at Pulau Tekong will increase the current flow in the Johor Straits, cause flooding in Johor and affect the fishermen's catches. Hydraulic modelling studies are done for our reclamation works to assess the

Column: 467

impact of reclamation on currents, tidal flows and water quality. They indicate that the reclamation at Tuas and Pulau Tekong will not have an adverse impact on the surrounding waters.

    Furthermore, water quality in the Johor Straits has also been jointly monitored on a regular basis by our Ministry of the Environment and Johor's Department of the Environment (DOE) since 1991. The results show that the water quality in the Johor Straits has remained unchanged even after reclamation works have started.

    Sir, Singapore has acted within its rights and obligations under international law in carrying out the reclamation works. During his visit to Malaysia in March this year, DPM Lee had indicated that if the Malaysians had concerns about the effects of the reclamation, they could send us a note and we would consider it. The Singapore Government is still waiting for a note from the Malaysians to understand their concerns more fully.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, notwithstanding the legality of Singapore's reclamation works, there appears to be a perception across the Causeway that we ought to have consulted before we undertook these works. May I ask whether there is any basis for such a request or expectation in law and also whether this observation of Rule No. 1 has been bilateral.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, to answer Mr Iswaran's question, let me first explain to the House why we reclaim land.

    Singapore is a small country. We are about 680 sq km. We need land. When Habibie said that we are a little red dot, he was not too far off the mark. If you look at the map, you will see Singapore in relation to Malaysia and Indonesia. Malaysia is about 330,000 sq km. So we are less than 1%, about 0.2%, the size of Malaysia. Our population is growing. Our need for land for schools, factories, housing is growing. That is the reason why we have to reclaim land. Without reclamation, we would not have Marine Parade, we would not have East Coast Parkway, we would not have the airport.

Column: 468

Without reclamation, we would not have Jurong Island, we would not have space for industries. Without reclamation, we would not have Marina South to expand our CBD. So that is the reason why we have to reclaim land. We are not a big country like Malaysia.

    Secondly, our reclamation is not a secret. We do not do reclamation quietly and sneak it through and suddenly we have the barges going to Pulau Tekong to reclaim land. Our plans are approved in Parliament, in this House. They are reviewed in all our concept plans. In fact, the reclamation of Pulau Tekong was reviewed in the 1991 Concept Plan, 11 years ago. The concept plans are revised every 10 years, and in the 2001 Concept Plan which we released last year, the reclamation plans are still there. Any member of the public can get access to these plans. If you are not in Singapore, you can just click on to www.ura.gov.sg and you can see these plans. So these are not secret plans, neither are they carried out surreptitiously or just on the spur of the moment. As I said earlier, we have looked at reclamation and we have carried out reclamation since the 1960s.

    To summarise, we are a small country, we need land. We have been reclaiming land for a very, very long time. Even then, after all the reclamations for the last 40 years and all the reclamations that we are going to carry out within our territorial waters, we will still be a small country, still smaller than Malaysia. So it is rather surprising that these allegations come out at this particular point in time, that we are thwarting their port development, that we are affecting their waters, or affecting them in many other ways.

    As I stated earlier, our reclamation works are done within our waters, in accordance with international law. We do not encroach on Malaysian territory. They do not affect navigation in the Johor Straits. They do not narrow the channel. They do not affect the water quality. The reclamation works that we do are a result of our own need for land. So I do not see why we have to consult Malaysia on a matter of sovereign concern.

Column: 469



    A few years ago, Malaysia was thinking about reclaiming some land off Johor, in the Straits. This was not too long ago, and the planned reclamation was very extensive. They did not see the need to consult us, neither did we make any noise about it.

    So given this, the fact that we need to reclaim, given the fact that we have made studies to ensure that the reclamation works do not have an impact, is it necessary for us to consult? Is it unreasonable for Singapore to want to continue to reclaim land to the maximum extent possible, within our territorial waters?

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Sir, may I ask the Minister, besides the studies done, what other measures have been taken by the Ministry to minimise any possible environmental impact on both Malaysia and Singapore? Is there any pollution screen being erected, or whatever is being taken?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: When the reclamation works are being done, first of all, the reclamation barges have to be properly managed, properly steered, and so on. As far as the actual works are concerned, there is a requirement for the reclamation works to be carried out in such a way that pollution and siltation are kept to a minimum. For example, the contractors are required to make use of siltation screens. These siltation screens are meant to block the silt from actually moving out of the area of reclamation.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung (Jurong): I would like to ask the Minister how binding is this 1995 agreement between the two countries, and could any one party alter it unilaterally, or interpret it differently.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: I think I should defer to my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, to answer this question. But as far as I know, it is an agreement that was signed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs for Singapore and the Minister for Foreign Affairs for Malaysia. It is an agreement that was ratified by both countries. It cannot be unilaterally altered by either party.

Column: 470



    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): I would like to ask the Minister, therefore, is there a basis for the Malaysians' expectations of us to stop work.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: We have carried out these works within our territorial waters. We have taken all the necessary steps to examine whether there would be any adverse impact on the surrounding waters. The reclamation profile has been properly calibrated to make sure that the impact on the environment is minimised, if not, completely eliminated. So as far as we are concerned, we have carried out all these works in accordance with our international obligations and within international laws. There is really no need for us to stop work at this point in time.

    Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Singapore's position is that it has no impact on shipping lanes, no effect on the environmental situation in the Straits. But given Malaysia's position that it has an impact and that it has indicated that it will send a note, looking forward, how do you see this being resolved, or would it be yet another issue in our tangle of problems?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as DPM Lee has asked the Malaysians to send us a note, I think it is important for us to wait until we receive such a note in order to understand more clearly what exactly are their concerns. Because right now, from what we read in the media, there are so many different allegations and some of these allegations contradict one another. So I think it is best for us to just calmly wait for the note to come.

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Aljunied): Sir, may I ask the Minister when we built the Second Link, although it was a joint project, we did quite substantial reclamation also for the purposes of the Second Link. Did the Malaysians raise any objections then?

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: No, they did not.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether, under the 1995 agreement, or under any international law, is Singapore obliged to

Column: 471

notify Malaysia, or consult Malaysia, when we want to do any reclamation.

    Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as I explained, the reclamation works are within our territorial waters and we have satisfied our international obligations. I do not see that there is a need for us to consult.

Column: 471

PATIENTS IN ACUTE HOSPITALS
(Fees for overstaying)


    3. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Health how many patients, who have overstayed in acute hospitals, have been charged with higher fees since the policy was implemented from March 2002.

    The Minister of State for Health (Dr Balaji Sadasivan) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member for Jalan Besar GRC, Dr Lily Neo, has asked how many patients who have overstayed in acute hospitals have been charged with higher fees. It is a policy that the Ministry of Health introduced in March 2002.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, to-date, only one patient has been charged full cost for four days of overstay in Class B2 ward of Singapore General Hospital (SGH). Despite financial counselling given to the patient, she chose not to be discharged home after she was certified medically fit. The reason she gave was that she did not want the hassle of returning to SGH for her daily outpatient radiotherapy treatment.

    Let me take this opportunity to explain our policy on overstayers in acute hospitals. Patients should be discharged from the acute hospitals when it is medically assessed that they no longer require inpatient medical care. Patients who still insist on staying in the hospitals should pay the full cost of their extended stay. In this way, we ensure that the heavily subsidised beds are taken up by patients who require inpatient care.

    In implementing this policy, I would like to reassure Singaporeans that we have put in place several safeguards. First,

Column: 472

our hospitals certify patients that they are medically fit for discharge based solely on medical grounds.

    Secondly, my Ministry is aware that some families may face difficulties in looking after patients at home upon their discharge for various social reasons. Some patients may also require step-down care. As such, the hospitals will assist the patients and their families to arrange for placements in step-down facilities, or home medical, or home nursing, for these patients. Patients and their families will be given sufficient time to make the necessary domestic adjustments. Full cost would only be charged from the seventh working day after the patients have been certified medically fit and after the hospital has placed them in appropriate step-down care facility, if necessary.

    Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): May I ask the Minister of State whether it is appropriate to implement the new subsidy for overstayers ruling as there is, at the moment, still a shortage of nursing homes and community hospital beds to discharge these patients? Moreover, the home care services are not adequate presently to have them sent home.

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, where step-down facilities cannot be found for the patient, or where the home nursing arrangement has not been arranged, the patient will not be discharged from the hospital, even if they are medically fit and even if the seven days have been exceeded.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin: Sir, may I ask the Minister of State what is the average occupancy rate of the acute hospitals?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the occupancy rate depends on whether the patients are in the subsidised or the paying class wards. Currently, in the subsidised wards, particularly in the C class wards, the occupancy rate is close to 100%.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister of State who certifies the discharge of overstaying patients?

Column: 473



    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the certification that the patient is medically fit will be done by a doctor. As in the acute hospitals, these patients are in departments that are under the care of consultants. The consultant in charge will be responsible for the patient being certified fit for discharge.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister of State whether it is right to put the onus on the doctor to certify the discharge of his patients? Do the doctors have enough time to investigate whether, socially, these patients are ready for discharge? Will he not agree with me that a patient cannot just be assessed physically, but also in totality?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the doctors will only certify on the medical grounds whether the patient is fit to be discharged. There are social problems involved in many of these cases and the social problems will be handled by the medical social worker. Where the medical social worker cannot solve the problem, meaning that the home nursing or home medical services cannot be arranged, then the patient will not be discharged. It is only when all arrangements can be made, and there have been seven days since the time the doctor has certified that the patient was medically fit to leave, it is only at that point will the patient be charged full rates.

    Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to discharging of patients, is it because of the present case mix policy, meaning there is a specific period of stay that a patient will get subsidy from the Government, after which there will be no subsidy? So I am wondering whether the patients are being discharged for this purpose to make sure that the hospitals do not have to pay on their own to treat those overstayers.

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, this policy has nothing to do with case mix. At this point in time, case mix has not been introduced for purposes of reimbursement of the hospital. So they have no reason to take case mix into consideration when discharging patients.

Column: 474

And should case mix be introduced at some point, we will ensure and insist that decisions on whether patients are discharged home or whether they are medically fit must be decided purely on medical criteria, and not on financial or case mix criteria.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, regarding the allocation of the medical social worker to a case where step-down care is needed, when does the medical social worker come into the picture?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Currently, it is the policy in many hospitals that looking at discharge of the patients and placement of the patient starts very early, sometimes even soon after admission, particularly with stroke patients. So the medical social workers may be involved very early in the management of the patients.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister of State whether it is correct to say that many overstayers are old people with no income or from families with low income and many of them with no family members who can look after them. May I ask whether this new ruling will jeopardise this group of people further financially and socially.

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the policy has been implemented for only a month and only one patient so far has been charged. In her case she had financial counselling and, for convenience, she wanted to stay in hospital. We will monitor the effects of this policy over the next few months. If there are any cases that have been discharged and it has caused undue suffering to the family or to the patient, they can bring it up with my Ministry or they can bring it up with me and we will look at it. But as this is a new policy that has been implemented for only one month, I cannot at this time tell the Member whether or not there will be anybody affected in such a manner. But we will monitor this.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister of State, since the average occupancy rate for the subsidised wards is

Column: 475

100%, is there any plan to increase the number of beds for the subsidised wards?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, currently there is a great demand for C class beds. We are reviewing the matter and, at this point, we have not made any decision on that.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister if there are plans for more step-down care services to be provided.

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, yes, there are plans for more step-down facilities, there are plans for new nursing homes and new step-down facilities to be built.

    Dr Lily Neo: Sir, may I ask the Minister of State whether it is correct to say that Medifund cannot be used for nursing homes and step-down care. Therefore, may I ask him whether his Ministry has created a group of people with special needs that cannot be met by our present schemes, in other words, have we created a group with no safety net for them? How would the Minister of State assure Singaporeans that nobody would be deprived of medical care as a result of lack of financial means?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the first premise that we have when a patient is discharged from the hospital is that the patient is medically fit to leave the hospital. So the question of the patient not receiving medical care does not come in. As long as a patient is in the acute hospital requiring medical care, Medifund will be available for the patient.

    Dr Lily Neo: Would the Minister not agree with me that many patients with disabilities are as a result of diseases? A good example he mentioned earlier was stroke. Therefore, how can he then refer to such cases as not medical-related cases and not needing Medifund?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think we need to make a distinction between medical problems and social

Column: 476

problems caused as a result of medical illness. When a patient comes to the hospital, the patient is ill, he is treated and medical care will be provided for him. But as a result of the medical illness, there are real social problems that may occur in that the person may be left disabled, without work and may have to make alternative financial arrangements to look after themselves. These are the social problems as a result of a medical illness. Where the social problems arise, they are referred to the medical social worker, who will then liaise with the various bodies responsible for taking care of providing support for people with financial problems, to help these people.

    Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, regarding the 100% occupancy rate of the C class wards, can the Minister of State assure us that those who are on the waiting list would be given the relevant medical attention and also at the C ward charges?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I said close to 100% because the occupancy rate fluctuates from day to day. Any patient who requires treatment will not be delayed. The patient will be admitted, put into a bed in another class, but the charges would remain, depending on what class the patient is admitted. So the various hospitals have contingency plans to deal with the situation when at one point in time there are not enough beds in that particular class.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, will the Minister of State tell whether a comatose patient is ever fit enough for discharge from the hospital?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: The decision on when a comatose patient is fit to leave an acute hospital will be a decision to be made by the doctor in charge. But there are comatose patients who leave the acute hospital to be transferred to a nursing home where they may remain for several months until they recover.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann: If the family of a comatose patient insists that the patient

Column: 477

be kept in the hospital, will this patient then be subjected to the policy of full charge?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: If an appropriate step-down facility is available for the patient and the arrangements have been made and there is a step-down facility that is available for the patient, it would make sense to move the patient to the step-down facility, because the cost of looking after the patient in an acute hospital is much higher than in a step-down facility. And that is the purpose why step-down facilities are built. So where a patient has an appropriate facility available for him and the family does not want the patient to move to that facility or the patient does not want that to happen, then the full charge will come in.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may ask the Minister of State, when will plans for the additional step-down facilities be implemented? When can we see the step-down facilities be done and in what percentage are we talking about?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the figures with me at this point in time on the details of the step-down facilities and when they will be available. But I will make this information available to Mr Steve Chia.

    Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines): Will the Minister of State not agree with me that the difference between the step-down facility and an acute hospital is one of subsidy, and will the patient not be put in a position where he is forced to take up an alternative provider of care where he does not enjoy any subsidy from the state in a situation like this?

    Dr Balaji Sadasivan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not agree. There is a difference between a step-down unit and an acute hospital. In an acute hospital, the level of medical care is more intensive and the patient is more acutely ill. They must jump out of their changing world, take charge and dare to venture into new territories.

    The Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry and Education (Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Motion of Thanks to the President.

We will prevail and emerge flying

    Sir, coming in at the tail end of the debate, I have had the privilege of listening to my colleagues' thoughtful and impassioned views on what Singapore needs to do to go forward and thrive in a very different world. I would like to comment on two priorities which stand out in the debate. The first, on what we need as individuals and, the second, on what we need as a society.

Twin priorities

    First, Singaporeans have to be more self-reliant, more robust as individuals, less dependent on Government. Many Members have expressed this need for greater resilience. Mr Seng Han Thong called for a camel spirit, not an ostrich spirit, among third-generation Singaporeans, and Dr Ong Seh Hong called for flying dragons, not earthworms - all these, no doubt, adding to the diversity of the new Singapore eco-system.

    Second, we have to redouble our efforts to stay together as a people. Government has to engage Singaporeans and, particularly, young Singaporeans, more actively and demonstrate that it is sincere in doing so. But Singaporeans have to themselves take ownership of efforts to build a strong Singapore society to enhance our multi-racial compact and carry forward the Singapore Cause that Mr Khaw Boon Wan spoke about.

A new culture

    Sir, I agree with the views expressed by many of my colleagues on these two priorities. At the core, we need a new culture, a new spirit, to take Singapore and Singaporeans forward in a new and very different world. We need a culture of rugged economic individualism. But it has

Column: 507

to be a culture that sees value in every citizen, celebrates alternative paths to success, and preserves a deep and abiding sense among all Singaporeans that we share a future together.

    We have no choice but to go the way of economic individualism. We have to encourage individuals to do well in the marketplace and earn great rewards. We need many more Singaporeans willing to stand out, do things differently, take a risk and occasionally go against the tide.

    Sir, we need this new culture not only to succeed in throwing up a stronger core of entrepreneurs, but to develop a more innovative people. It will be what gives us advantage against the competition and enables us to achieve good growth. This new culture will take time to evolve and it will have many implications for Singapore society. How do we ensure that those who do well in the market and earn higher incomes will not feel they stand apart from and above the rest? How far should we intervene in the market or seek to moderate the consequences of the market, whether through our fiscal policies, HDB subsidies or a social safety net? These are not trivial questions.

    Not many societies have succeeded in preserving a true spirit of togetherness and cohesion while holding to a spirit of enterprise and economic individualism. In most societies, economic individualism has worked against social cohesion. And policies and attitudes aimed at preserving social cohesion have often worked against a culture of enterprise and economic individualism.

    The Americans have the most enterprising culture among the advanced countries. In strictly economic terms, they have outperformed the rest. They have been able to do so because, more than other societies, Americans accept the free play of market forces. Individuals are more willing to adapt to changes, develop the next product, find the next market, look for the next opportunity. Americans accept as fair that individuals be rewarded in the market for their energies and their enterprise. They also welcome the best

Column: 508

and brightest foreigners into their society, give them a place and make them feel at home.

    The US has a wider inequality of incomes and wealth than most societies. But Americans tolerate inequality and even regard much of it as fair because of the reality and perception of social mobility in the US. It is a powerful and popular ethos - that anyone can get ahead if he puts in the effort. Contrast with Europe. Because there is less social mobility in European societies, there is greater popular demand in Europe for government to fight inequality than there is in the States.

    The Americans' non-egalitarian attitude to capitalism, and their greater acceptance of creative destruction in the corporate world, has produced superior economic outcomes. For every NTT DoCoMo or Vivendi, there are many more Wal-Marts, Intels and Microsofts. More important, jobs in the US have grown more rapidly than in any other advanced society over the last two decades. And they have had a faster increase in average productivity and standards of living. It has produced better results for the majority, not just the wealthy.

They rally around magnificently in crisis, as September 11th showed, and have a fervent belief in certain American ideals - but the US is otherwise not a tightly bound society. Wealthy Americans make large contributions to charity, as Madam Ho Geok Choo has mentioned, but it does not change the basic reality of a somewhat disparate society. The affluent and the upwardly-mobile live their lives quite separate from the less-skilled if they wish, moving out to the suburbs and even out of the cities altogether.

They succeeded as a people for 40 years, caught up with the West economically and surpassed the West in some areas. But Japan's system of

Column: 509

consensual decision-making and its highly egalitarian culture are now holding it back. The system is geared to avoiding pain, which means avoiding reform. Farmers, construction companies and corporate dinosaurs have greater influence on government policies than the needs of the overall economy. There is a profound loss of confidence.

    The Europeans have a more congenial and cohesive culture than the US. They are also absorbing lessons from the US on how to create an environment for growth, although of course the Europeans would not say they are learning from the US. They are cutting taxes, trying to roll back the welfare state and putting in place US-style capital market discipline. Embracing the Market

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have to embrace the market and accept the inequalities thrown up by the marketplace if we are to succeed in generating growth and creating jobs in our next phase of development. We cannot shrink from this challenge.

Column: 510

and the most energetic people from across their countries and regions.     But, ultimately, Sir, we have to measure success not by whether you get a university degree. We do not want to water down our standards, or lose the transparency of the assessment system which allows all students to compete on a fair basis for

Column: 515

entry into schools or the tertiary institutions. I am sure many of my colleagues in Parliament would join us in thinking through the changes which can be realistically achieved, and which represent real improvement over our current system.

Building on Strong Foundations

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we have come this far over 40 years because of extraordinary feats of leadership. We are building a new Singapore on a strong foundation - an aspiring people, a system of multiracialism and meritocracy that still makes us special, a labour movement that favours growth and good governance, fair and transparent. It has given Singapore a strong brand name in every capital across the world. No one seriously thinks of us as a little red dot.

    We cannot erode these assets, the core of our social capital. But we need new capabilities to succeed against the competition, and to keep our sense of well-being as a people. These new capabilities will require us to evolve a new, tougher social culture. We can do so. We are a young society, still mobile, without encrusted values and habits, still engaging our future with vigour. We will prevail, and emerge flying dragons.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann: Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak on the motion which I rise in support of.

    Sir, the President's Address is a timely and sobering reminder of the most serious challenge that confronts Singapore since independence. Rarely have we been faced with an uncertain future that requires the complete resolve and single-minded determination of the nation to overcome. Why are we so despondent about the future? It does not take much to see why.

    At the moment, unemployment is hovering around 5% and rising. Many of those who are unemployed are the middle aged and not very highly educated.

Column: 516

Neither are they in tune with the demands of the knowledge economy. Even as I am speaking now, I know for a fact that there are many, including those in the GLCs, who are now being retrenched or about to be retrenched because of the present state of the economy. We are speaking here of workers who are robbed of their dignity and pride to earn a decent living, not by circumstances of their own choosing, but by forces beyond their control. Sir, we are speaking here of the ineluctable sweep of the forces of globalisation that have taken many countries by storm. The breaking down of trade barriers would mean that for many, the goods and services that are now being produced, can be produced cheaper elsewhere. For many of the emerging economies with their teeming masses to feed, this would be a welcome opportunity indeed to provide cheap labour and to offer lower cost centres of production.

    On the other hand, for others, the availability of alternative venues of operation would mean that they no longer appear as attractive to foreign investors or as competitive as the foreign rivals. What results then is a steady flight of capital or a continuing relocation of operations to other venues which are cheaper to operate. When this happens, it is often the workers of closed down offices or factories who suffer. We see this when the labour-intensive industries here started to relocate to cheaper production centres in Indonesia, Malaysia and, in recent years, in China.

    Those of us who have had the good fortune of visiting China recently will attest to the rising and growing Chinese industrial might. This newfound confidence among the Chinese that comes with the rising level of wealth and the opening of the country is something which is self-evident. And greater still will be the confidence of the Chinese as China integrates itself further into the international trade through the WTO in the hope of becoming a first-world economy. The China that we know of today is a very different China that we knew of when our pioneers first stepped foot into that country 20 years ago or perhaps earlier. Then they were

Column: 517

eager to learn from us and looked upon us for guidance and investment capital. We know that they have since moved on to become like a giant vacuum that sucks up new investment capital in Asia. With a critical mass of more than one billion people and offering cheap labour in a huge market, it becomes increasingly difficult to justify why investors should choose Singapore as a preferred choice of investment. China has now become our most awesome competitor in the marketplace for investments.

    Sir, how should we deal with global competition and its effects? For many, the natural instinct is to fight it by shutting out foreign import. We have, in Singapore, chosen the path of riding the wave of globalisation. Rather than to resist it, we open up our market to outside competition. From finance to manufacturing and services, there is nothing here that is protected from competition. Foreign parties who feel that they can produce cheaper and perform better can expect to do business here. For many, the process has been painful. The consolidation of financial services to brace itself for competition from foreign banks will see more than 2,000 jobs being lost in the process. Sir, we are not talking of some statistics here. We are talking here of fathers and mothers without a job and an income to bring home so that there will be food on the table and the bills will be paid. Not only that, with the hollowing out of our industries, more jobs will be lost. Indeed, even if we are able to hunker down and wait through the present storm of economic recession, there is no assurance that life, as we know it, will be the same again.

    Sir, in his Address, the President did reiterate that in order for us to stay competitive, our business environment must be highly conducive. In keeping with this objective, we have stated that our infrastructure must continue to be world-class at competitive cost and our spirit of enterprise must be strong. I have no problems with the broadly stated intention of our Government. However, I

Column: 518

do have some reservations about how far a focus on continuing to improve our business environment is going to take us. In the present climate, I see that there are three major considerations in this approach.

    Firstly, I believe we are at the present level of development of our infrastructure where any further improvements would only bring about a diminishing return on our investments. The fact remains that economic outlook for the region will continue to remain weak in the next few years. We are, as they say, a good house in a bad neighbourhood. As long as there is no obvious upside in the outlook for the region, any further improvement to the infrastructure is going to only provide us with limited gains.

    Secondly, to foster a strong spirit of enterprise amongst Singaporeans requires a milieu that supports it. I am not that optimistic, Sir, in this regard. Over the years, we have not actively nurtured the growth of a strong body of small and medium enterprises. Instead, we have chosen to focus strongly on the GLCs as providing the engine of growth of our industry. For many of these GLCs, it is said that they have an unfair advantage on our local turf. It was not too long ago only that we learn of a GLC going into roast meat business here as well. It is arguable that for the GLCs, the yearning for contracts and business to stay alive is not of the same extent as the small and medium enterprises. The relative weakness of these desires should also arguably mean that our instinct, at least for the GLCs, for enterprise and business will not be as well-honed as it should have been.

    Additionally, when you have the best of brightest brought up in an environment that looks down at failures, whose primary pursuit of university education is to get well-paying secure jobs, and to avoid taking risk, one is not too hopeful that you can raise from this rank of Singaporeans many more successful entrepreneurs. Besides, even if we try to nurture in our young the spirit of enterprise, our ability to raise them in sufficient numbers is largely constrained by our lack of critical

Column: 519

mass. Both China and India have population sizes that exceed a billion each. We have four million. Sir, how can we effectively compete in number with human talent?

    Thirdly, looking primarily internally, as our Government's approach seems to suggest, for new initiatives to re-orientate our economy may inadvertently cause us to lose our broad focus. Let me illustrate. We have identified the life sciences as the next wave for our economy. In this regard, we are committing much of our resources towards preparing our people for this undertaking. We are also spending much time and effort building up infrastructure for research and development in life sciences in Singapore. Yet, we know that the centres for cutting edge research in life sciences are to be found in the west. Brave as our attempts may be, it will be many more years, Sir, before Singapore's research and development centres in the life sciences can come up to the standards of the west, if at all we get there. Sir, there are many who have asked the question of whether or not, we are better off if we had just leveraged on the more developed science industry of the west, either by more intensive collaboration or direct investment overseas, than try to establish a separate physical base in Singapore. My fear is identifying new growth areas for our country may well embark us on a physical expansion of resources that will give us a very limited outcome, when we may be better off building up our R&D industries overseas.

    Sir, some years ago in this Chamber, I had suggested that for us to survive in this country into the next millennium, we must increasingly look overseas for opportunities. Here, I am not just referring to industrial park developments or investment into areas that we are comfortable with. I am referring to, as I have alluded to earlier, investments into the new areas such as the life sciences and info-communications technologies. We have, over the years, built up a substantial amount of reserves. Our budget surplus between FY96 and FY2000 was in the region of $17.535 billion. Like a prudent farmer, we intend that these reserves be

Column: 520

stored for use in difficult times when the harvest is not so plentiful. Again, like the prudent farmer, we should also consider using these reserves and husbanding our resources to look to new sources of revenue if what we bring in from the field is not enough to provide for the family. With an accumulated surplus of approximately $17.535 billion, that is, in the last term of Parliament, we could use some of that money to buy a substantial stake, if not, a controlling stake in some of these carefully chosen world-class companies or companies with world-class potential. We could then leverage on our ownership of these companies by tapping on their management and technology know-how and in particular, their ability in brand management and promotion to give us a headstart in the new growth areas that we have identified. In other words, Sir, besides developing our bio-medical expertise, we should perhaps acquire leading bio-medical companies and be plugged in immediately into the world bio-medical grid. We could use this opportunity to send our best and brightest to learn from them, and hopefully, from this experience, we could build on a new generation of young Singaporeans who are savvy about the ways of international marketing and investments.

    Sir, at the present time, where the flow of information and mode of doing business is substantially different from the pre-Internet era, we must learn to think out of the box. Increasingly, we have to ask ourselves whether there is a continuing need to ensure that companies be rooted here to serve the economic interests of Singapore. In looking at the model that I have proposed earlier, we could perhaps own or control a Fortune 500 company, headquartered in the US or Europe, but allow it to be an outpost for Singaporeans to gain the relevant experience needed to keep Singapore in tune with the demands of the international market place. In this regard, we should perhaps take a leaf from the NUS, where we learned recently that they have, presumably to stay relevant, taken to setting up outposts outside of Singapore.

Column: 521



    Sir, if we are able to externalise our economy substantially and draw our revenue from this second wing, there will be less pressure on us if the Singapore economy is not doing as well. In fact, a thriving second wing derived through prudent investments and acquisitions could well allow us to have some inefficiency within our own economic sector. We do not, for instance, have to be so ruthless in making that segment of our workforce, the uneducated and middle-aged workers, redundant because they are not able to compete with their counterparts in India, China or Indochina. That way, we can keep a healthy balance between the need to stay competitive to make a living, which our investments and our stakeholdings outside of Singapore can provide, and the need to provide employment and to carry those Singaporeans who may not be able to look after themselves, without having to worry about cost efficiency.

    Sir, if we are serious about pushing our people to consider the world as our workplace, wherein to live and to work, I think we must be prepared to make some adjustments. I shall dwell on one, ie, education.

    It is widely known that amongst companies and businesses, there is one stumbling block in sending staff members overseas, and that has to be with the education of their children. Every parent in Singapore knows how important the second language is, and how important it is that they must do well in the second language if they are to do well overall in school. No serious parent will disagree that taking a child out of Singapore and placing him in an environment where the second language is hardly spoken or written, will have a major impact on his second language ability. Hence, for parents with school going children, it would almost be impossible to send them overseas, unless the centres of posting have Singapore style schools, or unless they can be assured that their children will not be severely disavantaged when they return.

Column: 522



    Sir, I know that the Ministry of Education has a policy of providing dispensation with the second language for the child for a year, if he went overseas and did some time there. However, for many parents, that may not be enough. The time has now come when the Ministry should perhaps review to see if they should be more flexible on the second language in order to ease at least one worry amongst Singaporeans who may choose to answer the call of the Government to work overseas.

    Sir, in overcoming the challenges ahead, we will have to rely on the larger home grown corporations since it is these corporations that will have the wherewithal to meet the demands that these challenges bring. Here, the GLCs, with their resources and close proximity to the Government, could well be suited for the work. Much has been said in this House about the role and performance of the GLCs. Long after the rumblings and grumblings in Parliament are over, there is still this rather common perception that GLCs could have been better run and should preferably not be staffed by senior managers who had spent the better of their careers in the public service. There is a common perception that part of our problem has to do with the policy of keeping our civil service young. What do we do with bright young senior army officers who we retire at 45 or, for that matter, young Permanent Secretaries who have served their time in service? It has been said that for many, they find their second careers in the GLCs.

    Sir, I have no doubt as to the mental ability and the integrity of civil servants who are seconded or chosen to spend their second career, or some say retirement years, in the GLCs. However, one wonders whether the skill sets involved in running a public organisation are the same as that of running an organisation that is oriented towards making money. Can we effectively move from the role of being a guardian to being an entrepreneur whose sole objective is to go out and earn more money for the company? It would be to our good fortune if they are able to make the mental switch. But then again,

Column: 523

what if they are not able to and are just content to coast along? Typically, in the West, if a large public listed company goes through a bad patch, the CEO and the senior management run the risk of losing their jobs. They are assessed by their current performance. It does not matter whether they had been good in the past. What should matter is how they are currently fairing compared to CEOs elsewhere of similar companies. Our difficulty here is the assumption that the talent pool is limited in Singapore and, therefore, if the civil servant has proven himself to be good at running a Ministry, he should, at the same time, be good at running a large corporation. There is a common perception that in Singapore, it is the same group of men circulating amongst the various corporations. And unlike the civil service, they could well be there for the long haul. Many have commented to me that the GLCs may turn in bad results, but for the senior management, life goes on. If the perception is true, is this how we want to run these corporations and expect them to be world-class companies?

    Sir, if part of the problem lies in our policy of keeping the civil service young and, of course, the uniformed services young, we should perhaps now begin to review this problem to see if we should extend the retirement age of senior officers, whether they be in the uniformed services or the civil service. Not all of the developed countries subscribe to this policy. Embarrassingly enough, at international conferences, we often find our civil servants amongst the youngest in the crowd, and sometimes by a margin of more than 10 years. Something must be said of experience and age. No amount of brilliance can be an adequate substitute for experience. By pushing back the retirement age for these very capable officers, I think we would have taken away the pressure to provide for their retirement in the private sector.

    Sir, there is no denying that we are at the most important crossroads of our nation's history. It is not an exaggeration to say that our future destiny will depend very much on how we are able to resolve the present crisis. Over the past few days

Column: 524

of debate in this Chamber, I have heard remarks and pleas that our Government and indeed our civil servants listen and not just hear the comments and suggestions on how we can better position Singapore for a better future. I sincerely hope that this time round, we will come out of this crisis stronger and better, with our bearings and policies enjoying the full confidence of the people, because our Government has taken serious account of the concerns of the silent majority.

    On that note, Sir, I support the motion.

    The Minister of State, Prime Minister's Office and Ministry of Community Development and Sports (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Motion of Thanks to the President moved by Mrs Lim Hwee Hua.

    Two days ago, I discussed with my grassroots leaders the President's Address and the debates in Parliament so far on the motion of thanks to the President. These grassroots leaders told me that having heard the President's Speech, they were a bit worried. And having heard the views expressed by the various MPs, they felt somewhat disappointed. Because the President's Speech sketched a scenario of a sea of roaring waves beset with crises. Subsequently, when they read the reports in the press, it appeared as though all the MPs were suggesting that everyone should be self-reliant. They felt that the Government seemed to have flinched. They asked me whether the Government had forgotten the strong mandate given to them by the voters some five months ago, with the understanding that the Government would bring them through the crisis.

    These grassroots leaders were very close to me, and that was why they were so candid in telling me their real feelings. This might well be the voice from the heart of many fellow Singaporeans. Of course, we must reassure them that the Government has been thinking of ways and means, all the time, to solve the problems of its people. If they do not believe, then they should listen to what Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong

Column: 525

had said yesterday about the measures to be taken to restructure and reform. They would know that the Government had put in a lot of thought. The Government has also set up a few high-level committees to look for solutions, in consultation with private and people sectors. However, the challenges we are facing are really very tough ones. These are very arduous and formidable challenges that cannot be solved by the Government alone. Therefore, my parliamentary colleagues here have suggested that all of us, from the top to the bottom, must be united and strive for self reliance, so that we will be able to cross this sea of roaring waves. If we are not willing to help ourselves, then no matter what the Government provides, in the end it will be of no avail.

    I remember a story about a man who was so lazy that the only thing he was willing to do was to open his mouth to be fed and to hold out his hands to be dressed. One day, his wife had to go back to her own village to visit her parents. Before she left home, she made a big biscuit and tied it with a string around the neck of her husband. She told the lazy man, "If you are hungry, just open your mouth and bite on the biscuit." A week later, she returned home to find her husband dead. He had only managed to eat the part of the biscuit nearer to his mouth. He was too lazy even to use his hands to reach for the part of the biscuit farther away from his mouth. As a result, he died of starvation. So, if we do not help ourselves, whatever the Government does, it will be quite useless in the end.

    In order to continue with our success, we must change this mentality of relying and depending on the Government to solve all problems. The President's address devoted much of its volume on the people factor. We are reminded that if we want to succeed, we must struggle and fight. In Singapore, opportunities are still abundant and everywhere. So long as we are prepared to work hard, there will be achievements.

    I feel that, in order to tackle these new challenges in a new economic and

Column: 526

political situation, all of us in Singapore, from the top to the bottom, should make some adjustments to our mindset and mentality.

    My colleagues here have already made some suggestions. Allow me to summarise these adjustments as three kinds of "a bit more", namely, a bit more courage, a bit more magnanimity and a bit more care and concern.

    Let me start with `a bit more courage'. This means that we must dare to innovate, dare to lead. We must decisively seize opportunities that come along, and be courageous and resolute in whatever we do. Otherwise, you will lose your opportunity. This is a big problem for Singapore, because we are blessed with a good natural environment. For example, our temperature here is quite constant. The weather will be the same as today, and so will the day after. There are no natural disasters to worry about. As a result, there may be a sense that if we do not work today, we can always work tomorrow, and if not, we can always wait until the day after tomorrow.

    This is not so elsewhere. In China, if you go to Huang Shan (the Yellow Mountain), today, you see the peak and you might see sunrise. But just a while later you may not see them because they are covered by the fog and clouds. So, the moment the fog is dispersed, you must immediately seize the opportunity to take in the magnificent view, otherwise you may just miss the most fantastic scenery you could see in your life. But, in Singapore, there is no thick fog. We see the same scenery day in and day out. Seizing an opportunity to view certain scenic spot does not seem to be that important.

    We must also dare to venture, dare to adjust, dare to advance and dare to retreat. We must never be too swayed by considerations of minor gain and loss, and hesitate over what move to make or shilly-shally. We must remember that paths are made by men walking over them. If we want to go somewhere and there is no access road, create your own way. So, if we want to start a business, use the road

Column: 527

that we have created for it. There is of course a cost to it, but then this is what entrepreneurship is all about. You can recover the cost by charging others who use the road started by you.

    Next, we must dare to express ourselves. We must also dare to take responsibility for what we say. Whenever we tell our young professionals that the Government is asking people to make suggestions and contribute ideas, their first response is inevitably, "Where are the OB markers?" Are there any out-of-bound areas? When we keep thinking about the out-of-bound areas, then we might just as well shut up and do not talk. So in that way, we would not be able to have a good exchange of ideas. In my view and experience, so long as we speak according to our conscience, in the interest of the nation and our fellow citizens, it should not be deemed to be out-of-bound even if we hold views different from the government. That is my experience as a civil servant for more than 20 years.

    Next, we must dare to face failure. We must remember that failure is the mother of success. So when we start a business, we may make some mistakes and lose some money. So long as we learn from these we can treat the losses as though you are paying the tuition fees to learn. So, when we fall down, pick yourself up, lift up your head and try again. Hongkongers are full of such adventurous spirit. So they have a proverb: `A great gentleman can bend and can be straight'. To them, there are only temporary set-backs but no permanent failures. Take one step backwards, and you get more space in front of you. So, taking a step backward today may mean few steps forward in the days to come. You can start all over again.

    We must also dare to learn new skills, to go into new industries, new ventures. We must be able to turn quickly. You must remember that heaven never seals off all the exits. Every cloud has a silver lining. There is always a way out. Opportunities and success are out there waiting for you. .

    Next is not to be too agitated by noises or the comments from our neighbours.

Column: 528

We must not be unduly troubled by what they say. We must put the truth in perspective. We must remember that important issues must be solved with reason and enlightenment. So if we all have a little more courage and can do all these things that I have suggested, then I think we will have more confidence in ourselves.

    Of course, we must have `a little bit more magnanimity'. With a little bit more magnanimity, we shall be able to accept divergent views from other people. This may be difficult. As it is often said that too many people generate too much noise, it becomes chaotic. But, remember, there is also this saying that "among three people walking together, there will be one who is good enough to be my teacher". In other words, there is always someone from whom we can learn something. So we can talk, we can debate, we can discuss, and from all these we will all learn something from one another. So long as we are magnanimous, listen to and willing to accept the views of others, then we will be able to find order in chaos. Even in a chaotic state, we can learn a lot of things.

    We must not judge a person by his success or failure alone. We should not reckon the person by the clothes he puts on. Today, we are successful, we wear branded clothes and drive a luxury car. But, you cannot guarantee to have all these luxuries forever. Many of our fellow citizens argue in forum page that we must have broader yardsticks to measure success or failure, and not by money alone. And success or failure is not permanent. Many of us like to sing. There are two lines in a very popular song by the name of Gujue zhao Jin Chen (Ancient Moon Shining on Today's Dust) which says, "Victory and defeat cannot last very long; rise or fall happens in a flash." So we are successful today, but tomorrow we may fail. So this is the turn of tide. When you see somebody fails, do not say that he is finished, because tomorrow he may rise up again. So we must be more magnanimous in this sense.

    At the same time, we must dare to accept talents from other places who can

Column: 529

contribute different styles and ideas, and who can supplement our shortcomings with their strong points. We must be able to leverage on their greater abilities to our benefit. But we normally look only for their shortcomings, and say, "Look, we are better than they are." But, few would recognise others' strength and learn from them. If we can learn from other people's good points to strengthen ourselves so that we will have a good team and a strong community. If there are 10 people with the same ability, their combined strength is one multiplied by 10. But, if they have different capabilities, then their combined strength is 10 multiplied by 10, and you have 100 - this is what we call "synergy".

    When we are magnanimous, we will be able to understand and hence tolerate the different cultures and different religions. We must realise that "all roads lead to Rome", we could reach the same goal by different means. We must mutually respect one another. We must strengthen our mutual trust, and fortify the foundation of racial and religious harmony.

    We must also esteem the wisdom and strength of the masses and the community. Although not everyone in a community has high education, he or she knows the needs of his or her own community better. We must encourage each community to resolve its own problems using its own ways and means. We must not crave for a new Government ministry to be set up just whenever we are faced with a new problem, and then complain that there is too much bureaucracy. Once we have a new ministry, we must have new procedures. Once we have procedures, we cannot escape having bureaucracy. So if we have too many Government ministries, we are encouraging more bureaucracy. Since we all dislike bureaucracy, we might as well go and solve our problems ourselves rather than asking the Government to set up more ministries and then complain: "Why is there so much bureaucracy?".

    Next, is to have `a little more care and concern'. We must remember that the

Column: 530

new economy is full of roaring waves, and people, including ourselves, will get tired or injured. When this happens, where do we go back to? We should go back to our family. But many of us feel that our family structure has been weakened. When the young people are urged to set up their families, they say, "Where do we have time?" These are matters that we must consider seriously. We must strengthen the family fabric. We must not forget that the family is the basic building block of the society's foundation. It is our emotional support and our focus of care. The family is a haven for us in the towering waves of the oceans. So, however strong the ship may be, in the face of the towering waves in a storm, we must find a haven.

    Next, more care means we must take care of the man-in-the-street, our little men, the ordinary citizens. The inspiration from our popular local song Xiao Ren Wu De Xin Sheng (Voices from the Hearts of the Little People) and the hot-selling local films, Money No Enough and I Not Stupid is that we should not forget the ordinary and less successful compatriots among us. We must remember that the prosperity of our nation and the opportunities that bring up the successful ones among us are actually created through the joint efforts of everyone, including the not so successful.

    In our society, about 90% of our people are ordinary men-in-the-street, and they contribute very greatly to our society. We must not forget them. We must not forget our roots. We must also propound the fine traditions of self-help - that is, the more successful ones should help the less successful ones to catch up, and cope with the development of the society and the nation. In the traditional societies, this is very important. The places that our ancestors came from, like Indonesia, China, India, have this kind of tradition. During the colonial days, the colonial masters did not care much about the life or death of the people under their rule. Yet, this spirit of self-help and self-reliance, enabled our society and the various communities to carry on, to survive and prosper. However, when the Government becomes too successful and

Column: 531

too efficient, the people begin to look to the Government for help, and then this spirit of self-help and self-reliance in the community becomes weakened. So I feel that we must rediscover the communal self-help spirit and tradition, so that we could have more care and concern among our people. What we want to see more is problems solved through the care and concern coming from within the community, and not some ad hoc measures dished out by the Government through the civil servants. We must also care for the retrenched, the unemployed and the less fortunate people among us, because they are also part of our community.

    I remember when I was in Shanghai two weeks ago, I exchanged views with a Chinese unionist on helping the unemployed and retrenched. He told me, "In China, we try to educate the community that a worker has been retrenched not because he is not good enough, but because changes in the labour market has caused his job to be lost. So this can happen to anyone, including you and I. Hence we should not look down on the retrenched and the unemployed. Tomorrow, it may well be us. So, we should help each other. Show some care and concern for them, they will feel they have not been forgotten by society, and they will have the courage to start all over again."

    I think we can learn from this attitude, and show a little more care and concern for others. We must also not forget our elders. As it is said in Chinese, "Honour your own elders and extend it to other people's elders. Love your young and extend the love to other people's young as well." While it is good to look after my own family, we should look beyond that. We should transcend our family to look after and care for other people, beyond our family.

    We want to promote volunteerism in our society. We must encourage more people to volunteer in social works. We must strengthen our social heartware. A little more courage, a little more magnanimity and a little more care and

Column: 532

concern can go a long way in strengthening our social fabric. Start from a little here, a little there and build up our social cohesion. Then, we will be moving in the right direction.

    We can find inspiration in the Presidential Address. Move forward courageously, and get rid of our kiasu (afraid to lose) and kiasi (afraid to die) mentality. We will be able to be bold and courageous, but with caution and prudence. Then we can reach the state of baijia zhengming (letting a hundred schools of thought contend). We can then lay the strong foundation for our future development in the new century. Some 100 years ago, the founders of Singapore came from various parts of Asia. On the basis of three "little bit more": more courage, more magnanimity and more care and concern for the people, they have built up this miracle in the form of a prosperous Singapore.     I do not really need to explain the meaning of the Whip and the Cabinet system of collective leadership to the former Speaker. But as there are many new MPs here, let me take some time to explain.

Lifting of Whip

    The party Whip is an appointment that can be found in many political parties represented in all legislatures all over the world, particularly in countries that follow a Westminster or British style of Parliamentary democracy, like Singapore.

    The duties of the party Whip vary from party to party, but primarily they involve maintaining the party's voting strength, by ensuring that members attend important Parliamentary debates and support their party when a division is called. Simply put, the party Whip builds and maintains party discipline.

    It is in the interest of the people for political parties to be disciplined. In Parliamentary elections, the parties come first. Candidates stand for election under a party logo, unless they are independent candidates. The people want to be assured that the MPs they have voted for

Column: 543

remain faithful to the party platform they were elected on. A party whose members are unable to maintain reasonable consensus on its policy positions will find it difficult to instill confidence in it, and get the support of, the voters.

This goes against the grain of party-based Parliamentary democracy. We will be lifting the Whip on the motion on Nominated Members of Parliament. Already, we can see some MPs marshalling others for their cause. Do we want to see this for every issue?

    But how much leeway is given to MPs, and how to do it, are the prerogatives of the individual political party. Different political parties have different comfort levels when it comes to party discipline. Some are less tolerant of public dissent amongst their members, others more so. But none will agree that they can do away with party discipline completely.

Collective ministerial responsibility

    Soo Khoon also suggested that we should let Ministers state their individual views freely before the final decision is taken on a subject.

    This is being done. Ministers are expected to contribute to the debate on a subject before a decision is taken on the matter. Their inputs are given in Cabinet, before the matter comes to Parliament.

    We do not let Ministers speak discordantly outside Cabinet because of the principle of collective ministerial responsibility. This principle is another cornerstone of Westminster-style Parliamentary democracy. It is, in fact, enshrined in Article 24(2) of our Constitution. There are two reasons for this principle.

    First, collective ministerial responsibility enhances the accountability of the Government.

    In our Parliamentary democracy, whichever party has a majority in Parliament will form the Government. But the Government, led by the Prime Minister and his Cabinet Ministers, is not at liberty to do whatever it wishes. It is accountable to Parliament.

    The principle of collective responsibility means that there is an agreement between the Prime Minister and his Cabinet colleagues that they will stand together as a team when accounting for their actions before Parliament.

    Discussions within Cabinet are therefore secret. Once a decision on an issue or a policy has been reached, Cabinet Ministers will take the same public position. It cannot be otherwise. Imagine for a moment that the principle of collective responsibility did not exist. If a problem occurs, it is only too tempting for a Cabinet Minister to claim, "I did not really agree with this policy, so I cannot be held responsible." This principle of collective responsibility is therefore to

Column: 545

    Secondly, collective ministerial responsibility enhances inter-ministry co-ordination. Most of the important problems we face as a nation are complex and cut across the portfolios of individual Ministers and Ministries. The Government's policies and initiatives must be evaluated in the light of their effects upon various aspects of our society. They must be carefully coordinated to avoid unnecessary duplication or, worse, mutual contradiction.     Several MPs have spoken on our relations with Malaysia. Yeo Guat Kwang said that one union leader could not understand why the Malaysians were so angry with Singapore.

    Water is another complicated issue between our two countries. In fact, it has been a constant source of tension since our independence.

    The picture that has been recently painted in the Malaysian media is one of an arrogant, selfish Singapore profiteering from our purchase of raw water from Johor. As in the land reclamation issue, this picture is skewed to arouse feelings and resentment against Singapore.

    Let me give you an example. We have been accused by a Malaysian newspaper of raking in huge profits of RM600 million annually, by selling the water we get from Johor at 3 sen per thousand gallons, to ships which call at Singapore.

    Water sold to ships calling at our ports does attract high tariffs, but this is only because we do not want to encourage this kind of demand. We sell only a small quantity of water to ships, about 1 million gallons per day, which is less than 1% of Singapore's total water demand. The revenue Singapore gets from this sale, I wish, was near the RM600 million figure, but it is not. Last year, Singapore's gross revenue from our sale of water to ships totalled about RM40 million.

    The key unhappiness, however, is in the current price of 3 sen that we are paying for raw water.

In addition, we had been prepared to vary the Points of Agreement (POA) on Malayan Railway Land, and offer Malaysia additional plots of land for joint development.

    All these concessions that Singapore had offered under the bilateral package must be taken into account when considering the price Singapore is willing to pay for water under a new agreement.

    But for Singapore, this issue goes beyond money. The 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements are international treaties, legally binding on Singapore and Malaysia. They are guaranteed by both governments in the 1965 Separation Agreement and cannot be varied except as provided for within the Agreements, or by mutual consent. But we were prepared to consider an increase in the price of existing water within the bilateral package and as a gesture of goodwill to help conclude a deal.

    I bring up this point because at the height of the furore over water, certain comments by the Malaysian media troubled us. They seemed to suggest that Malaysia should unilaterally amend the terms of the existing Water Agreements, if resolution could not be reached on a new price for existing water. For example, a New Straits Times editorial of 30th January commented:

    "By (Singapore) suggesting that these (water) agreements continue to apply by default because the Johor state government failed to re-negotiate the price structure after 25 years in 1986 and 1987, it is simply playing hard to get."

    The same editorial suggested that the issue of water be viewed as a business transaction - agree to a price, seal the deal, or part with no hard feelings and look elsewhere for water. In other words, if

    But it is not so simple. Both sides can walk away from the negotiations on a new water agreement if we cannot reach an agreement. However, both sides have to honour the existing 1961 and 1962 Water Agreements. As I mentioned earlier, these two agreements were confirmed and guaranteed by both governments in the 1965 Separation Agreement, also known as the Independence of Singapore Agreement. Any breach of the Water Agreements would also call into question the Separation Agreement, and undermine our very existence. This is totally unacceptable.

    I think it is high time we explored a different approach to water supply from Malaysia. I do not want our relations with Malaysia to be always strained by this issue. It is not healthy for our two countries to be always locked in dispute. It is unwise to allow this one issue to sour bilateral relations at all levels and on all fronts. It prevents us from co-operating in strategic areas of mutual benefit. The long-term interests of our two countries might be better served if we can remove this constant thorn in our bilateral relations.

    The sensitivity of this water issue goes back to the Separation. On 9th August 1965, the very day of our independence, Tunku Abdul Rahman told the British High Commissioner in Malaya:

    "If Singapore's foreign policy is prejudicial to Malaysia's interests, we could always bring pressure to bear on them by threatening to turn off the water in Johor."
